Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Theoretical and Experimental Characterization of the Dynamics of Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded by the Environmental Chemistry program of the Chemistry Division at the national Science Foundation, investigates the chemical and physical properties of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) particles produced in the atmosphere by reactions of gas-phase organic chemicals (emitted by vegetation, industrial and transportation sources) with ozone and hydroxyl radicals. SOA is a complex mixture of thousands of low-volatility organic species that condense on preexisting atmospheric particles and form a large fraction of atmospheric particulates that impact human health and alter visibility. The project trains students to work in an interdisciplinary team that includes fundamental physical chemists, applied aerosol physicists and atmospheric chemists.

This collaborative project brings together research groups from Boston College (BC) and Aerodyne Research, Inc. (ARI) with expertise in SOA production and measurement of submicron SOA particle properties and a group at the University of California, Berkeley (UCB) with capabilities in modeling the thermodynamic and molecular dynamic properties of liquid, glassy and crystalline organic materials. The project supports a series of laboratory experiments, directed by Professor Paul Davidovits at BC and Dr. Charles Kolb at ARI, that characterize the dynamic properties of mixtures of SOA-like surrogate chemicals as well as laboratory generated SOA particles. The UCB theoretical team, led by Professor David Chandler, is formulating models to reproduce the dynamic properties of SOA measured in thin film deposition and fine particle reactive uptake experiments, with the goal of predicting the impact of relative humidity and temperature on thermodynamic and kinetic properties of SOA/water systems found in the atmosphere. The coupling of fundamental, theoretical, and experimental dynamics of glassy organic material help clarify and codify the roles of SOA in cloud formation, cloud and aerosol radiative properties and cloud precipitation. The resulting theoretical tools is used by the atmospheric science community to better predict and parameterize SOA particle climate impacts and SOA particle inhalation exposures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Secondary organic aerosols are complex mixtures of thousands of low-volatility organic compounds that occur as particulate matter in the atmosphere and impact cloud formation, visibility, human health and climate. A large part of the impact of these aerosol particles is determined by their thermodynamic and dynamic physical state — they could be liquid, or glassy. Their thermodynamic and dynamic states in turn are determined by atmospheric conditions such as temperature, relative humidity, and the rates at which these conditions change. In this work we attempted to gain a fundamental physical understanding of the thermodynamic and dynamic state of these particles using theoretical tools and simple models. 

 

We started our approach with attempting to predict the glassy properties of mixtures of materials. A glass is an amorphous solid, with a disordered, liquid-like microscopic structure. On its way to becoming a glass, a liquid exhibits ‘supercooled’ behavior — its dynamics becomes heterogeneous in space and time, i.e., some regions are mobile while others are immobile, and this changes with time; and its dynamical properties such as diffusion, viscosity, and relaxation time (time taken to relax to equilibrium after a perturbation) begin to show dramatic non-linear increases as temperature decreases. Theories of glassy dynamics and glass formation have thus far explained the behavior of single components. Our first step was to create a model that successfully describes the glassy behavior of a mixture of components. Based on the approach of dynamical facilitation theory, a theory for glassy behavior and glass formation, we developed a model that accounts for multiple components. We were able to use this model to predict relaxation behavior for a wide variety of experimental data on mixtures. This work is available at https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.08557. We showed that a mixture of materials effectively behaves as a single material with its own effective energy scale, which determines its dynamical properties. We derived an expression for how this effective energy scale can be calculated given the energy scales of the individual components of the mixture, and also present a formula for the glass transition temperature of a mixture, i.e., the temperature at which a supercooled liquid transitions into a glass. 

 

In context of secondary organic aerosols, the ability to calculate the glass transition temperature can be important to determine the height and temperature conditions at which the rising liquid aerosol becomes a glass. This in turn determines the ability of the aerosol particle to nucleate a cloud. Typically, the glass transition temperature of a mixture is calculated using empirical relations such as the Gordon–Taylor equation that are not based on any microscopic physical theories of glassy behavior. We present, for the first time, a physical picture for glassy behavior in a mixture, and associated equations for relaxation time and the glass transition temperature.

 

In addition, we have also made a fundamental advance in the physics of phase separation between glass and liquid phases. In our work available here, https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.04747, (published in Physical Review Letters(120, 260602), 2018), we introduce the concept of and calculate a dynamical interfacial tension between a liquid and a glassy phase. Interfacial tension is a thermodynamic quantity that represents the free energy per unit interface between two phases. Treating liquids and glasses as two dynamic phases, phases that differ not in their spatial arrangement but in their spatio-temporal arrangement, we showed that a dynamical interfacial tension exists between them. 

One consequence of a dynamical interfacial tension is that mobile particles tend to occur closer together in space and time, rather than further apart. This concept helps us consider glass formation of aerosol particles via a decrease in humidity. As aerosol particles rise, a rapid decrease in humidity causes water (a relatively mobile particle compared to the material in an organic aerosol) to leave the particles making them glassy. The interface between the water-rich liquid aerosol, and the water-poor glassy aerosol, which can also be the interface at which chemical reactions occur, can be described using the physical principles we introduced in this work.
